Sociology and Anthropology

Program at a Glance

Anthropology is the study of human beings, past and present. To understand the full sweep and complexity of cultures across all of human history, anthropology draws and builds upon knowledge from the social and biological sciences as well as the humanities and physical sciences. A central concern of anthropologists is the application of knowledge to the solution of human problems. Anthropology has four main areas of focus: sociocultural anthropology, biological anthropology, archaeology, and linguistic anthropology.

Minors

Anthropology Minor
Sociology Minor

Students benefit from:

  • Extensive field experience — including internships, community-based research, and collaborative, faculty-led projects
  • Customizable programs for tailored study — allowing the pursuit of unique interests
  • A flexible curriculum that easily accommodates double majors — with various other programs in the School of Humanities and Social Sciences and beyond
  • Small classes and seminars — to drive deep engagement and collaboration
  • Close mentorship from faculty with diverse expertise — particularly in fields of health, the environment, nonprofit and community development, and urban and ethnic studies

Careers

TCNJ anthropology students become socially aware, culturally sensitive, committed community members who are well-prepared to pursue professional careers in a range of fields or acceptance into top graduate programs.

Internships

Most Anthropology students complete at least one internship — and getting hired after graduation is a frequent occurrence. Students can receive academic credit for internships at almost any type of organization related to their studies.

Study Abroad

To broaden their perspective and deepen their social and cultural intelligence, Anthropology students are encouraged to study abroad. TCNJ’s Center for Global Engagement offers over 100 study abroad sites to choose from worldwide.

Mentored Student Research

Anthropology students are encouraged to carry out research with faculty mentors. Each year, the department’s faculty offer research courses to give students the opportunity to work closely with them on cutting-edge research projects. Students may also choose to carry out independent research with faculty support. Some students choose to carry out a two-semester, research-based Senior Thesis as their culminating major Capstone project.
